docTitle.titlePart:
Handling Incompatibilities
between Services deployed on
IP-based Networks

byline.docAuthor: Mario Kolberg and Evan H. Magill

front.div:
The Telecommunications Industry has undergone major paradigm shifts in
the previous years[4]. One of these is the shift from circuit-switched
networks towards packet-switched networks. There is hardly any doubt
anymore that IP will be the ubiquitous transport protocol for multimedia of
the future.
At present the work towards Internet telephony has attracted a lot of
attention. Two standards have been developed: SIP [1] by the Internet
Engineering Task Force (IETF) and H.323 [2] by the International
Telecommunications Union (ITU).
As has been shown by an initial study[5] the rapid deployment of services
on top of SIP is hindered by a well known problem - Feature Interactions.
As in traditional telephony networks Feature Interactions are also a serious
problem between services deployed on IP-based networks. In this paper, the
technological changes in SIP compared to the traditional telephony network
are highlighted as well as the impact of the changed business environment.
In a multi-service provider environment (as encouraged by a SIP
environment) the feature interaction problem is regarded to be an even
more pressing issue. Services of different providers from a multitude of
service creators are likely to interwork. This in turn leads to the fact that the
ad-hoc approaches to service interaction handling commonly applied in the
industry today will not be sufficient anymore.
In this paper a new approach addressing these changes is introduced and the
results of a case study are presented.
